text:
So, welcome to this panel discussion
where we are looking closer

at an innovative telco partnership
looking to disrupt the industry.
My name is Mea Thompson,

and aside from being a digital telco
fanatic and an eSIM geek,

I'm also the CCO and founder of
unconnected.org, an organization

where we're looking to connect
1 billion people to the internet.

So, let's start
introducing these impressive panels.
So, with me

I've got Robin Major from Moflix
and to make sure I'm not hogging the mic,

maybe you can do a quick intro of yourself.
For sure.
Thanks, Mia.
So, I'm Robin Major,

I'm the the Chief Revenue
officer of Moflix.
We're an AWS native software vendor

which is bringing disruptive
digital propositions to the telco market.
Fantastic.
Then we got Sudhanshu Sinha,
from Totogi.
The mic is yours.
Who are you and why are you on this panel?

Thank you so much, Mea.
And thanks for putting me on this panel.

My name is Sudhanshu Sinha and I am the Senior
Vice president at TelcoDR,

and I'm also one of the founding
executive members of Totogi.

At Totogi we are trying to reimagine BSS
from ground up by writing

it completely natively on AWS
and a fully planetary scale platform
which is available

for anybody to try on AWS Marketplace
with the click of a button.
Well, welcome to the panel.
Glad to have you here.

And last but definitely not least,
is Visu Sontam from AWS.

First of all,
thank you for having us in the studio.

And you don't need to introduce AWS too much,
but introduce yourself, please.
Sure. Thank you, Mea.
I'm Visu Sontam, I'm an SA Leader

in Go-to-market team driving
OSS/BSS opportunity in telco.
Welcome to

the panel.
And let's take a little step back.
So, as I'm working to connect to 40% of

the world's population
currently not connected, it's very clear

that the other half is taking connectivity
for granted.

Consumer expectations have changed
dramatically

and our lives are moving
more and more online.

And we've been talking at conferences
like this one for ages about disrupting

telcos with lean digital operating models
and cloud native technology.
And we've done that for some time.

But it seems like the industry is moving
slow.

Other industries, however,
those seem to be getting it right,

and we're seeing new, innovative,
bold players coming in,

a new breed of operators,
and some of them outside

of the telco industry.
And they're really starting

to disrupt this industry,
but they are very slow to launch.

So the question for today is,
how can we support new innovative

operators to enter the market quicker,
and how will the partnership

between AWS, Totogi, and Moflix enable
just that?

So, let me kick off with asking you, Robin,
a question

before we get into the actual solution
of what you guys are launching,
why do you see the need for this

telco partnership
and how is the industry changing?
That's a great question.

I think, as you said to most people, it's
pretty obvious that consumer expectations

have changed dramatically since
the introduction of smartphones. And,
you know, there's a whole range of

exciting digital services
offerings out there and things
like entertainment, finance, social media,

transportation, I think you name it,
there's something out there

where they make it just easy for people
to onboard themselves and manage

their entire service relationship
through a simple, intuitive digital app.

We even see examples of that happening
in the telco industry with people like

WhatsApp coming in and really
sort of boldly changing the game.
But, I think it's kind of true to form that

that the telco players
really have been slow to come to the party

and when they have arrived
they've arrived carrying a load of baggage

from the way
that they've just always done things.

Really putting it bluntly,
I think they've wasted the last decade

rather than sort
of trying to get up to speed with what

the rest of the world is doing,
really looking inwardly

at a whole wave of transformation programs
focused on

incremental improvements
to IT processes and legacy IT
systems,

rather than reimagining themselves
through the lens of what's really needed
from these new modern consumers.

I love it when someone says,
"to put it bluntly". I was laughing

because that means some hard
truth is coming out.
But like I mentioned before,

and you kind of touched on
about the new disruptors coming in.

How do you see them
impacting the way that telco is evolving?

Yeah, so these new players
come to the same party,

but they've arrived with a bold new vision
for how to win the hearts and minds

of these consumers and innovative
ways of monetizing those relationships.
You know, those are the guys

who are really going to win in this
new digital economy. They
understand

that a new way of thinking about the telco
operating model is required

and the new way of thinking
about consumer engagement.

And they've come with a radical new
approach for implementing
lean operating processes

for disruptive ways
of monetizing relationships.

That really is putting them
in pole position when it comes to
to this new way of doing business.
And we'll be seeing them

driving whole new ways of doing things
in a much more radical way.

That's going
to change the nature of the industry.

I think we're also seeing them realize
that they can't get the kind of results

they're looking for by partnering with the
same old telco vendors that the industry

has become reliant on for so many years
and they're looking to partner

with, you know, disruptive thought leaders
like the people on this panel.
You know, we're all

providing solutions based on the AWS
stack.

We're natively looking for ways of
of creating value

that allow, you know, operators
to

disrupt their markets
and find new ways of doing things.

You know, that's what the ANTO,
the AWS native telco partnership is all about.

And now it's a really exciting
time to be in telco again.
That's exciting times indeed.

And I saw you were nodding
and following the conversation as well.

And so Sudhanshu, just before we started
airing this outside in the halls

with the masses of people here at MWC,
we had a conversation

and you mentioned it's really crucial
for these new innovative

operators to be able to launch quicker
and more streamlined.

Do you mind
just elaborating a little bit on that?
Oh, absolutely.

Let me start with an anecdote and then
sort of build that story from there on.

A few years ago, I met with the founder
of an MVNO who wanted to launch

an MVNO combining digital content for
Indian diaspora in the European market.
And he wanted to combine

the content with connectivity
and deliver it to the end customers.

Unfortunately, it took him nine months
to figure out a BSS stack,

which will help him
to launch an MVP into the market.

Because of which, the OTT content
partners were not so patient.
They decided to launch their app directly

into the market, completely
killing the business model for this MVNO.

Subsequently,
the investors pulled out the backing

and the MVNO was dead
within the next six months.

Unfortunately, this story is not just true
for this MVNO or this market.
It's globally applicable.

In fact,
the data shows that only up to 20% of the
MVNO's actually succeed after
their launch.

And it comes down to three
or four complex problems which we have,
we are dealing as an industry.

We have a complicated process of sourcing,
we have complicated systems.
The integration takes too long

and then your runway is too small
to prove your viability in the market.

Imagine if we can flip it around
and give every invention out there

an opportunity to jumpstart their brand
and take that MVP to the market.

The amount of innovation
which will come out will be unprecedented.

And this is exactly
what this industry needs.

And that's what we are
trying to do with this coalition.

I was going to start with saying
that's a great story,
but it wasn't a great story

because it didn't end up very good
for the company you talked about.

But it does really show the need
for us to be able to find a better way
of onboarding new MVNO's.
So Visu, from AWS,

tell us a bit more why Totogi and Moflix.
Why, would you say, that

this is such a great
groundbreaking partnership?
Sure.
So, AWS has a vast number of partners

allowing customers to choose
based on their needs. And Totogi

and Moflix are strategic
partners in BSS space.
Moflix offering

digital all-inclusive, all-in telco app
and also
Totogi offering real time

charging and ability
for operators to do network intelligence,
it's a perfect combination.

So together with this combination,
operators can innovate faster
and also leverage AWS capabilities
to be ahead of the curve.

So
it sounds like a great partnership.

You got all the pieces there for for
the perfect recipe, for the perfect dish.

But you mentioned before
about the ANTO concept.
Tell us a bit more about the ANTO.

Sure. So, together
ANTO- we came up with that together

AWS, Totogi, and Moflix
came up with a concept called ANTO.

ANTO is AWS Native Telco Operator
where operators, as Sudhanshu

mentioned, operators can use the combined solution
together as infrastructure, as a code
and spin up instances,
spin up the whole solution within minutes

and able to come up with the solution
so that they innovate faster.
They can think about

more about their business
rather than thinking about infrastructure

and how the underlying aspect,
but to think about their businesses.
Thank you.

And Robin, Visu was talking about ANTO.
You mentioned ANTO before.
What does ANTO mean to you?
Look me I think ANTO is a game changer.
It's as simple as that.
The AWS

Native Telco Operator is
is the first end-to-end telco

in a box solution that leverages
the native capabilities of AWS

to provide a full telco
stack that an MVNO or an MNO

who wants to be disruptive
can launch by pressing

one single button
in the AWS marketplace

and you know, it brings together
some of the most disruptive

ISVs in the telco space today
starting with Totogi and Moflix,

and we're really sort of changing the way
that people think about how quickly

you can instantiate one of these
new greenfield digital brands.

I think the other thing
that's really cool for me about ANTO is,

you know, whilst
everyone on this panel here

is part of the sort of the core
of the coalition, it's an ecosystem play.

So over time we'll be looking to expand
the footprint and the capability

as we identify more AWS
native ISV's who think that they can

contribute to the solution
and add value to the footprint.

So if there are
any, you know, budding AWS

native ISV's out there
who think that they can contribute to this

and you know, let's get in touch
and see

if we can talk about bringing them into
the ANTO coalition.

Awesome. And one question though,
because you mentioned before that it took
nine months for this

for the telco to find a BSS
and then they went bust.
And you're saying

now that you've got this new solution
that can launch a telco a lot quicker.
How much quicker are we talking?

Yeah, I mean, you know,
Visu said "in minutes".

It is in minutes, but it's certainly under
an hour. When you know a traditional IT

telco stack deployment is easily
going to take you a year.

So it's a huge improvement
in terms of the expectations.

So you can launch an operator in an hour.
[Robin] That's what we're saying.
[Mea] Okay.
So I guess Sudhanshu, looking at ANTO

except
for being able to launch in an hour.

What are the other opportunities
that you see with this concept from Totogi?

I think the opportunity
and the potential is enormous, right?

Totogi and Moflix have the same opportunity
to do to BSS what Salesforce

and Tableau did to CRM and revenue
recognition, which is to completely change

the way people think about these platforms
of this business
goals of revenue recognition.

Can I just add in that- can I ask,
why did you choose AWS?

Can you add that in as well?
[Sudhanshu] For sure, for sure.

I mean, I think before I go into that,
I think for me,

like I said, the opportunity to do sales,
you know, opportunity for Totogi

and Moflix
to do to BSS what Salesforce and,
you know,

Tableau did for the CRM
then the revenue recognition,
which is to come up with a globally available parity

scale platform,
which delivers on your business

goals, but it's paid by use.
And anybody can get started

and up and running and start
doing their business with these platforms.

I think with the collaboration
with Moflix,

we have taken that journey a step further
where you can not only monetize

your network, but you can take these plans
to the consumer with a first class

experience
which today's generations expect.

Now, as far
as why we decided to go with AWS

was ability to sit in this panel
and talk a little about it.

But that was not the reason.
We started two years ago doing this.
And there were three key reasons

why we chose AWS. Number one,
that speed of expansion.

Today
they have 31 regions, 90 local zones,

and they're continuing to expand.
Every region they deploy,

it's a vehicle
for us to attack that market.

So me and Robin can go
and tell that market that

now our platform is available
for you to try.

Number two,
their speed of innovation.

They ship product and innovation faster
than anybody, any other hyperscaler.
And every innovation

they ship is a vehicle
for us to show our value add on top of it.

Last but not the least, is the AWS marketplace,
which is a great procurement engine

but simplifies the buying process
of this technology in a click of a button.

I think with that with my original story,
I talked about all the complexities

and I think AWS is helping us
to solve all three of them in one shot.

So that's why we decided
to go with AWS.
And it's a perfect bridge.
Visu you must love that answer, obviously.

But coming from AWS,
what is the key business impact

that you aim to,
kind of, focus at or deliver on?
Definitely. I'm loving this discussion.
I knew you were going to say that.
The strategic partnership
of AWS, Moflix, and Totogi,

and bringing the SaaS solution
out of the AWS marketplace

where customers can really enable...
take the SaaS

and don't have to worry about going
for- taking from AWS marketplace.
That's a key thing

I want to add. AWS marketplace
so that customers can experiment

faster, fail fast,
fail cheap. At the same time.
Okay, they can have the-

they can be ahead of the curve
because of the SaaS environments.

And what I'm liking,
this is entirely cloud native

way they have built using managed
Kubernetes,

purpose-built databases, as well as logging
and monitoring and governance with AWS,
and serverless

capabilities with AWS,
step functions, and DynamoDB.

So that's
what is completely native AWS-

Native AWS way,
which is really going to help

the customers be ahead of the curve
and also they can see

how they can monetize
that as 5G as well as
enabling MVNO's and operators.
Fantastic. Thank you.

And as we're running closer
to the end of this discussion,
I want to put

you all on the spot though,
and to give you a bit of a challenge.

So, I want you all to answer one question
and I want you

to target it to a different type
of personality or person.
Right?

So the question I want you to answer
is, what value

do you bring to the telco industry?
With "you" being like the partnership,
I mean. So answer less than 10 seconds

and I'm looking,
Robin, you're closest to me.
So, I'm going to start with you.

So, answer the question what value
do you bring to the telco industry?

But you need to answer it like you are
talking to a Chief Commercial Officer.
And the clock starts now.
That's a tough shot.
I'll give you my best shot.

So if I'm a Chief
Commercial Officer, then ANTO

allows me to respond to market pressures
really quickly

and launch a greenfield
digital operator in record time.

It reduces the time to revenue
for my new business and allows me

to be really creative in terms of the way

My teams are free to have good ideas

to monetize
the service in really innovative ways

and to do things
that are just being focused on

boosting my NPS, my engagement
and my top and bottom line.
Well, you didn't keep it to 10 seconds.
I counted to 12 in my head, but that's all right.

So Sudhanshu, I guess you get 8 seconds
then just kind of even it out. Sorry.
[Robin] Sorry.

And so, you answer the same question,
What value do bring, and you are chatting with

the Chief Information Officer,
How would you pitch it?

So number
one is responding to the business quickly.

I think that's the primary goal,
responding to the business quickly,

ability to experiment faster, ability
to retain smarter

talents and attract
better talents towards their workforce.

And in the end, doing all of this
without spending millions of dollars.

That's my message for the CIO. [Mea] Okay,
that was 9 seconds.
So, we're down one second for the last one.
No, I'm just joking. You get 10 seconds.
He definitely pulled it back.
Yeah, I know. So, you get the same question.

You're speaking with the Chief
Financial Officer,

how would you phrase it to get them on
board?

Sure. Ability to save billions of dollars-
[Mea] Well, that's a good start.

[Visu] by using infrastructure as code
and with the best solution between

Totogi and Moflix,
and rather than just depending on
going with the

whole procurement and leveraging
the existing infrastructure.

Well, damn that was 10 seconds
sharp. Well, to kind of round this up,
I want to thank you all for your time

on this panel
and your presence. It's been great

to learn more about the ANTO concept
and I'm really looking forward

to see what the future brings for you guys
and for the telco industry.

If someone that sees
this video wants to understand more

about this partnership
and get some more information,

there will be a link underneath

So, thank you so much for joining me
on this panel today.
Fantastic. Thank you, Mea.
Thank you.
Thank you.
